I really enjoyed HuniePop. It's 'spiritual successor', though I know it isn't supposed to be a sequel or anything... isn't as much as I hoped it would be.

1.) Depth
The character depth is lacking - I wish there had been more storyline other than 'get views'. I wish that we could see more art in the actual game than when we're exiting or entering it. I really wanted to feel like I had some kind of connection to the characters. I felt like I was experiencing the game through a brick wall.

2.) Reward
While I'm clicking, it doesn't really feel like there's a reward to spurn me onward, no, oh
date: hey! YAY! I get a picture of x! This makes the clicking seem worth it." The only reward was whatever trophy you received from the viewers and maybe
recommended:
POSSIBLY an achievement.

3.) Timing
The time frame of the game is really what has disappointed me most - I know Kyu said there were 21 days to reach the goal
hoursPlayed: but I didn't think that was the ONLY goal to be reached. I thought there would be a tier level system
voteText: where you had deadlines to earn each trophy before the axe was swung. Honestly I have no idea how ANYONE could get the diamond trophy without some type of cheat. The more girls you get
helpfulPercent: the more any type of strategy applied devolves and becomes a mass of panic and a race of cigarettes and booze. Twenty-one days isn't nearly enough to achieve anything. I haven't been able to even achieve the first trophy level.\n\nYeah
votesHelpful: you can keep playing that save file after the 21 days
votesTotal:
but what's the point if there is no reward and all you get is a 'try again'? It sucked.

4.) Shopping
Another thing that bothered me about the timing is how long it would take the girls to go shop at the store. Picking up 20 or more cigarettes is no big deal - it can take ten in-game minutes if you click fast enough... but buying ONE condom can take EIGHT hours if you don't click? I know that part of the game is risking the seedy hotel. I don't want to risk
votesFunny: I WANT to play it safe and having to wait/click through to MAYBE get the chance to pick ONE condom is the absolute worst.\n\nAs a suggestion
commentsCount: why not make condoms a 3-pack like actual retail stores? I don't think that would break the game
column16: especially if it was bound to one character until all three were used and it had a cool-down (like spell casting in other games). I'd really like to justify making trips to the store
column17: I really
column18:
really would. This totally subtracted from my gaming experience.

5.) Art
On a positive note
column19: while others don't seem to like it...  I love the art! I love when artists branch out from their previous style and introduce something new. Lailani is a sweetheart - she's my favorite design. I love the bold colors of her outfits and her obviously Hawaiian theme."

reviewText:
Cons:
No nudity, just tease photos.
Unlockable characters from previous game not included.

I really enjoyed this game. It was addictive, like Hunie Pop, but for different reasons. It is a really engaging resource/time management game. Even though I have already beaten the game 100%, I still can't stop playing it. I wish there was more to do in it. Even though the cast of characters was bigger, I still felt like they could have included more. More characters, costumes and photos would have been great unlockables. Thankfully, Rockhard mode is out. I hope these guys continue the Hunie franchise. Despite my minor gripes, I liked this more than Hunie Pop. I highly recommend this game.

reviewText: It is not a traditional sequel to Huniepop. The game changes to a more idle and upgrade type of game. Unlike the first Huniepop however it doesn't have too much content. For example in the first Huniepop you could unlock more girls. While in this rendition you have a total of 20 girls all who are unlocked at the start. I would recommend this as a casual distraction for a couple of hours or two. It not a bad game by anymeans (It can be quite diffcult if your not paying attenion). Its certainly not for everyone but if you are a fan of idle upgrade games this is a good game for you. I'd give this game a 6/10 not bad but not super deep.

reviewText:
This game can be described as farmville with a stress element or, alternatively, a slightly advanced cookie clicker.

Whilst I did not expect a mechanical sequel to HuniePop, which by all means is an astoundingly good game, I had hoped that the themes and personalities of that game would resound through Hunie Cam Studios. That is the outlook with which I played this game, and it is sadly where I find the game most lacking. Whilst the outspoken and highly recognizable cast of the first game is present (at least for the most part, judging by a first play through), they are reduced to simple statistics in a much greater sense.

The cast only expresses itself through grunts or short sentances to mark completion of a task, refusal to act, and so on; there is no direct interaction whatsoever. Meanwhile the new characters, with only a few exceptions, appear lackluster or just plain absurdly designed. (The haywire design of Zoey springs to mind.) Kyu herself is present, but only to give you a basic rundown of the mechanics, and comment on your performance upon completion. In short, the characters of HuniePop are present in name only, and the cast in generall brings little of interest to the table.

Mechanically, this is a timed resource management game, where collecting earned resources has been made tedious just to push another few linear upgrade trees on the player. Ultimately, the threat of bancrupcy is faint, and only emergent if you push yourself for a highscore. To my knowledge, it would be fully possible to comlete" the game with an unleveled starting character
date: just bouncing back and forth between three buildings. Mechanically there is little to no replay value; the difference between the starting characters you will be offered is typically miniscule. In its predecessor
recommended: this was counteracted by the surprisingly well developed (albeit stereotypical) characters. With that aspect lacking

reviewText: I don't usually bother writing reviews, but I feel like I should for this one simply to balance out the unwarranted hate it's been getting.\n\nSo yeah, I actually liked HunieCam Studio. It's not the deepest game, nor is it HuniePop 2, but it was never meant to be such (and it was never promised as such either, despite what some people apparently deluded themselves into thinking). But it's a fun little time waster with a pretty decent amount of challenge if you fancy going for the achievements, and for a spin-off game that costs less than my lunch, that's more than enough to be worth my money.

reviewText:
I'm a sucker for management simulators. Love 'em. I loved HuniePop, so I, of course, had to try HunieCam Studio. Here's the number one thing that bugs me: HuniePop was cute, and while you were a rather creepy womanizer, it was personal. This?

This is straight up human trafficking.

It's so much less personal and interactive with the girls, and the fact that things like cocaine and STDs are involved just leaves a bad taste in my mouth. I get it. It's a management sim. It's a broad picture, and it's not meant to be personal.  But some stuff was simply unnecessary. Maybe it's a level of individual comfort. Maybe I shouldn't be playing this game because of that, and leave it to the people who it doesn't bother. It lacks the (admittedly questionable) charm of the original HuniePop, and, at least to me, has a dark undertone that just leaves me feeling remarkably more uneasy than one lame dude getting it on with nine girls, a cat, an alien, and a fairy. It's not like they're trying to hide that it's disgusting, but declaring the fact that it's deplorable doesn't make it any less so.

The mechanics of the game aren't my favourite--the timer runs rather quickly, and it stresses me out like nobody's business, especially when I have to decide whether to collect or to speed things up. They're not awful, but they're not stellar. They neither make nor break the game. They're completely unremarkable, honestly.

Of course, there's no satisfaction like watching numbers climb at an exponential rate, so I'll most likely keep playing it, but I'd be lying if I said it wasn't a little upsetting.

reviewText:
It's no HuniePop, but it's not a bad game at all to me! I'm glad they managed to bring back the old girls of HuniePop (with the exception of Momo, Celeste, and Venus). While it can get a bit tedious, wanting to beat your fan scores kind of make it worth it to see just how high you can go. Though, I kind of wished that there were more achievements to the game. I know, I know, 16 is a LOT of achievements, but there are a few others that would have been pretty cool.

Examples could be something like:

Sell Out - Get Platinum by gaining fans using only promos
Alcohol Anarchy - Get Gold with a staff of alcoholics without using the wine box or basket
Diamond Standard - Get Diamond on all save files

Something like those, I think it'd be kind of cool and give the achievement completionists, like me, a little bit more of a challenge, I guess?

But anyway, back to the game. It's not for EVERYONE, but if you're into mobile games (which, let's be honest, this reminds me of one) or you have the patience for it, this game is worth it. I think the new art style is pretty cute and at the very least I can play the game without worrying TOO much about passing people behind me, since it looks like an innocent game at a GLANCE (during gameplay at least, since the character and title screens aren't so innocent XD)

But yeah...long story short, if you're into ♥♥♥♥♥ trophies and heart eyes (♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥), this game is for you!

reviewText: Going into this game, I wasn't sure if I liked it. The same old complaints that have been said about it being vastly different in gameplay and art style than HuniePop were taken into consideration, yet I still enjoyed this game. My first complete playthrough of the full twenty one days was a learning experience (preceeded by a few game overs). On the second playthrough, I knew what to expect and how to succeed over my past playthrough, and I found myself having more fun and trying things I never did before, which was a fun learning experience itself.\n\nFor those who are sceptical about the game, it's dirt cheap. I suggest giving it two completed playthroughs, one to learn the basics, and the second to explore the game's offerings, trying out different combinations and techniques you may have avoided before.

reviewText: Ugly art style + shallow gameplay. Not comparable to HuniePop.\n\nAfter giving this game another try, I decided to change the vote from down to up. The game pacing is done pretty well and the resource management aspect is well designed. Unfortunately there seems to be a optimal strategy if you look into these numbers. It'd be better if the developers introduce more random events into the game and make it more like FTL. Currently the only elements of randomness are:girls for hire, ads, STD, and inventories. reviewText:
Honestly a very disappointing Spin-off from such a good game.

The main disappointment in which you CAN compare this game to Hunipop is he Writing and humour. THERE ISN'T ANY!

Huniepop was different from other match-3 games because of two main things: Well drawn scantily clad anime waifus and a decent amount of well written self-conscious diaglogue. Hunicam however has barely any dialogue, mostly just Kyu's tutorial which is delivered fairly half-assedly.  The meat of the game trys to keep you invloved by forcing you to click buildins whilst you're managing your girls, but honestly it's just boring. And i like management games! I was really looking forward to the idea of this game, but it's just not enjoyable to play.

Sorry Huniepot, you're one of my favourite developers but i didn't like the way you decided to go with this game. Best of luck with your next one though!

reviewText:
I loved Huniepop, and I love this game as well, although mostly for different reasons, and I don't think it deserves some of the criticism it's been getting since its launch.

Although there is a clicking element in the game, there's not often much waiting, and the game gets more and more fast-paced as you go on, which is quite different from an average clicker or management sim, which is part of the reason I enjoy it so much.

The time elapses constantly as you play, only pausing when you go into a menu, giving the game a bit of a frantic feel, which is nice.

What I think ties this game to Huniepop, besides the characters, is the wit. It's not much, but the voice acting has plenty of snark and nuance.

The only complaint I have about the game is the short format. It's not cumulative in nature (besides the extra outfits and hairstyles you can get with the points you earn at the end of each game. That said, it's given me plenty of reason to go in again and try to get as many points as possible.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
A short clicker game with LOTS of adult references and HEAVY sex humor. You spend most of your time interacting with buildings, icons, and text. It isn't bad per se, it's well made and feels like the devs took their time to complete it.

The game is painfully short, each run takes about an hour and a half. After your second run, you'll likely have fleshed out the entire game. With about 2.5 hours clocked, I enjoyed it and its humor a great deal but feel like their could have been more to it. Namely, I would have liked to see more interaction with the girls and to have had more than the 21 days you are given to build Kyu's Porno Empire.

HunieCam Studio delivers the same parody of the fanservice dating-sim genre as HuniePop before it did, this time taking the sexual references to 11. You can't go more than a few seconds without seeing a ♥♥♥♥♥ on screen or reading a promo for ♥♥♥♥ fetishes. If you've been around the block on the Internet, you'll most likely get a chuckle from it and sometimes you'll have to pause the game to laugh a good minute.

Unfortunately for such a fanservicey game, there's no sexuality or nudity on screen ever. It would have been nice to have a bonus mode after landing a Big ♥♥♥♥ Trophy (Yes! You get ♥♥♥♥ Trophies!) where you can interact with the actual camgirls doing their thing. But for 6 bucks, it is what it is. It's also a bummer to have no bejeweled-styled sex puzzle games, but there's always hype for HuniePop 2 some day.

If you want some dirty laughs and to work out your clicking muscles for a few hours, or to catch up on your Hunie Waifus, give this game a go. If you're more of a Puritan looking for an in-depth management game, Roller Coaster Tycoon World or Punch Club are much greater adventures to be had.

I'm mixed to give this game a recommendation, but Koons is a great guy who isn't afraid of making dirty games, which is much needed in this era of fear of objectifying anyone and anything. I recommend HunieCam Studio with high hopes that this series will continue to grow.

reviewText:
In high school I took an entrepreneurship class. Essentially a class that teaches you how to set up and run a business. One of the lessons I learned was the amount of research and science companies put into small things that you normally don't think about. An example of this is in the colors companies use in their signs. When you see red your blood pressure increases, making you feel hungrier and more excitable in the process. Thus why a lot of food companies primarily use red in their logos and in advertising.


This game follows none of that, only that you will fall into debt because you don't have enough chubby Latino girls.

reviewText:
Tbh, I had somewhat low expectations for this game. HuniePop is a favorite of mine, because of the art style, music, and addictive gameplay. I immedietely regretting the $7USD that this game cost me.

Look at my playtime. Stare at that number. Let it sink in that an asexual female has wasted that much time with this game.

It's no HuniePop, certainly, but I enjoyed the hell out of it. I pulled an all-nighter trying to get all of the achievements (which I still haven't quite managed). The character designs are cute. The voice acting can get a bit repetitive (and in the case of certain characters is flat-out annoying to begin with), but my fondness for the original Huniepop girls (and the relaxing background music) stopped me from muting my computer.

Huniepot clearly cares about the games they make, and the love they put in makes me love them, as well. I don't think that everyone will agree with me that the game is worth $7 upfront, but considering how much time I have killed and will likely continue to kill in HunieCam Studio, I'd say that my money was well spent.

reviewText:
HuniePop was an excellent Bejewelled/match 3 game wrapped with a dodgy dating sim, that has gameplay good enough for me to go back and play again long after I have 100%ed the achievements.

HunieCam Studios is a terrible resource manager wrapped with a dodgy concept that goes nowhere and has zero replay value after completion.

The gameplay is woeful and as many before me have mentioned can be mastered on the 2nd or 3rd playthrough, there is no challenge just time wasting.  HuniePop had a sense of accomplishment on winning the game or even just successfully shagging a girl.  In HunieCam you will have passed the top score with 10 days to go and might as well walk off and start making dinner while the timer runs down to finish the game without you.  (Yes I literally did this)

HunieCam commits the greatest of sins; not being fun.

reviewText:
Alrighty, I actually found this game pretty fun. Basically, this could be considered a watered down tycoon game, but it is a fun, silly, and surpisingly addicting take on these kind of games.

You run a cam girl company, and make a ton of fans with your line up of girl streamers.... yeah.

You have 21 days to run this business and get a grade at the end of the days, ranging from bronze to diamond depending on the amount of fans you have at the end of day 21. You can still play after the 21 days on that save file too if you want.

After my first 21 days, finding out how to get closer and closer to that *cough* wonderful diamond trophy felt rewarding. The game doesn't give a super obvious hint on how to become op enough for the diamond, so coming up with a plan that works FeelsGoodMan.

BUT, this game does kinda bite the dust after getting around the 7th playthrough or so (at leas for me) where it's the same thing over again, and I had a good idea how to make this experience easy. So, as a result, it was sort of a grind for the last few achievements. But it didn't really bother me that much, I was still engaged in the game. ( And they added a Rock Hard Mode as an update for those people who were dank memers in this game. Gj HuniePot)

So, I do recommend this game if you want a short and fun experience. It had me hooked for the whole week, and I don't regret selling my entire inventory for this... What? I'm not loaded with moolah, stop looking at me like that!

reviewText:
I liked the original Huniepop, so I decided to pick this up to support the developers. The mechanics of it are decent and smooth, very simple - you recruit girls to make money for you through cam shows, and you gain fans from having your girls take pictures. You spend money and make money in turns.

Unfortunately, while there is a cast of recurring and new characters and the mechanics are kept simple, its a very short, very skimpy game. You're given 21 days to have your girls get as many fans as possible, and once those 21 days are up, that's it, game over for that save file. You're told to either go back and start again to earn more tokens so you can change the many girls' wardrobes (which is also fine), or continue to play on the same file for fun.

You end up with a game that cuts you off at the knees just as things are getting good, and that's frustrating in its own way. I would like to see more added to HunieCam, but more than likely that's a dream that's never coming true.

Overall, a disappointing game, but not the worst one out there. 5/10.

I would like to see maybe some DLC that makes it so you can see more art stills or something, but for a small simple game, i thought it was done nicely.

reviewText:
As a huge fan of HuniePop (one copy for myself, and several for friends), it would be pretty difficult to be more disappointed in a game.

Gameplay-wise, it's just a typical clicker game, but instead of being free, it costs $7. There's no depth to this game. It is not impossible to go from new to this game to a virtual master (obtaining the most challenging trophy) in two 1.5 hour playthroughs. If you want a fun (and free) clicker game, try Time Clickers.

There is no story other than a couple of sentences about building a cam empire. In terms of characters, it is quite possibly the most disappointing aspect of the game. HuniePop had a cast of memorable characters that encouraged attachment, or at the very least, your attention. These characters return in HunieCam Studio, but they have been robbed of all personality (not to mention dialogue, with all characters but one having maybe 10 words of spoken dialogue). Each character is boiled down to 2 static traits, that's it. As to the new characters, I played through this game 7 times or so, and I can't recall a single new character's name, much less anything about their personality.

The music is also a huge disappointment compared to HuniePop, if nothing else due to being so scarce. HuniePop had a soundtrack worth buying, but this game has almost nothing.

Now, on to the art. This was probably the most divisive aspect of this game among fans. I wish I could say the reaction was overblown, but it really isn't. The art in this game is atrocious. The creator stated that the art was inspired by Facebook style games, but I honestlly don't see it. After the relatively simple, but extremely expressive and clean art of HuniePop, the art of HunieCam Studio is probably the most disappointing aspect. I really wish the creator would have listened to fans last year when the vast majority of fans opposed the change in art, but hopefully he will learn from this.

Overall, this game is not worth your money. I played through the game several times trying to pin down my opinion of it, but in the end it wasn't worth it. It might have been worth something if this review dissuades someone from buying this game, and using that $7 on something that deserves it more.
